Dialog.Value: Soon, Wrath. He will return.
Wrath. This explains much.
Servant One.
You should not have destroyed the Opticrons.
The droids exist so that we may know you. You exist so that you may serve our master.
You have no need to know my every movement. The droids were an insult.
We determine our needs.
Why have you come to Rishi? Not because of the droids....
We will come to that.
The droids spoke of a ritual. They said that "when he returns, all stars will die."
The sayings of the Opticrons must be interpreted with care. That is our work, not yours.
You are an instrument of our master's will. Perhaps you have spent too much time serving among the fleets and the Dark Council.
First Ilum, then Makeb, and on the list goes... what does not threaten the Emperor is not your concern. We fear you forget this.
Your last instructions were to keep the Empire strong for the Emperor's return. Should I proceed differently?
Not yet--not so long as you remember your role. We are at a delicate juncture, and you must trust in us.
The events on those planets concerned the fate of the entire Empire. I will not ignore our enemies.
We are at a delicate juncture. Your past choices are of mixed merit; trust that we will inform you when you are needed.
I've forgotten nothing. You need not be concerned.
Good. We are at a delicate juncture. Trust that if there are matters of import, you will be told.
Now, I understand Darth Vowrawn sought to meet you here. He has committed crimes against the Hand.
What sort of crimes?
He sought to learn our secrets and interrogated a Servant. We believe he is fleeing to the unmapped stars of the Rishi Maze.
Did he reach you? If he left this world only recently, we might still find him.
Vowrawn stood in that very spot. He could not be gone long--he can still be caught.
Excellent. The Hand will see to it.
If he attempted to contact me, he failed. I felt a presence here and came to investigate.
Then our search must continue. He will not elude the Hand forever.
Vowrawn was the one to tell me of the droids. He must have known they belonged to the Hand.
I will see to his death myself.
No. The chase may be long, and you shall be needed soon. Others will make certain he is punished.
We will not ask that you stay your saber and return to the tranquility of our fortress. Your edge must not be dulled.
Have faith that all questions, all concerns, will shortly be resolved. The Emperor is returning, and we will fuel his flame.
As always, I am the Emperor's loyal servant.
Then we chose well.
Your cryptic words mean nothing. How will he return? What does it mean to "fuel his flame"?
Fear not. It will be glorious.
Be ready, mighty Wrath. Soon you will fulfill your true destiny.
I will not be patronized, and I am no one's slave. I am reconsidering our arrangement, Servant.
If your master desires my aid, he can speak to me himself.
You have made... a grievous error.
You are making a grievous error, Wrath.
No. The error was yours.
This was unexpected.
When he returns, there will be peace.
The Wrath can see! Do not permit this!
When he returns, all stars will die.
The Wrath disobeys programming! Darkness must be preserved!
When he returns, there will be silence.
The Wrath cannot know! The ritual must proceed!
A pleasure, as always.
My good Wrath, you look the same as ever. How many Jedi have you slain today?
We meet again, Vowrawn.
In all seriousness--how are you? I understand you've been working tirelessly for our Empire.
Is it satisfying, your craft? Putting down Hutts and cults here and there?
Our Empire is surrounded by those who would destroy us. I stand in their way. You know this.
I do, and I admire your handiwork--yet I worry for your future.
These deeds must be done. But I grow weary of running the errands of others.
As I feared. I worry for you, Wrath--and for your future.
We are not here to discuss my passion for destruction. What do you want?
I want to understand you, Wrath, and I want to discuss your future.
The Republic claims the Emperor is dead, but I hear rumors to the contrary. The game pieces are moving.
Speak plainly.
Consider this: the last Wrath of the Emperor served in that position for centuries, only departing after turning traitor.
As I understand, you never chose to become the Wrath--the position was thrust upon you. What is it you truly desire?
I seek the ultimate test. I seek to measure myself through battle, and to become greater.
"Through victory, my chains are broken." There is no victory without contest.
I wish to rule. I wish to exert my will and my vision upon the Empire and the Sith. That is our order's way.
So it is. And though it may one day cause us conflict, I would not see your path inhibited.
I am the Emperor's Wrath. I do not seek--I am our master's fury embodied, and to doubt that is to voice treason.
Ah, Wrath--forgive the confused words of an old man. I worry for you, and forget the glory of serving our Emperor.
I have a gift to aid your endeavors. I have come upon indications that you are being watched, and have been for some time.
These spies are mechanical, but ingeniously hidden using combinations of ancient and modern technology, welded into form using the Force.
Tell me how to find these droids. I would have words with them.
How did you learn about this? And who is behind these spies?
"How" must remain a secret so long as the spies may be listening. "Who" is a mystery to me. But we can find answers.
You make a bold claim. Why come for me? What do you want out of this?
If unknown forces are tracking you, spying upon you, then surely that concerns us all?
An associate of mine with connections in the Gree Enclave manufactured this: a device to reveal your foe.
Use it to reclaim your privacy if you wish... or to look upon the face of your watchers.
How does it work?
Activation is simple, but I'd draw your foes somewhere remote--the jungle, perhaps--to avoid interference.
There is more I'd offer you, but not until I'm certain we are alone.
The spies will soon be ash and scrap. Then we speak of the consequences.
Your assistance will not be forgotten, Lord Vowrawn. Once again, our deals bear fruit.
Those who seek to manipulate me come to bloody ends, Vowrawn. If these spies are your enemies instead of mine....
...then they will not deal the first blow, and you will know.
I will remain on Rishi as long as I can. Good hunting, Wrath.
Be careful of those machines. I don't know the extent of their strength.
Hey, Captain--it's Beryl. Pirates are scrambling, so you must've done something, but no retrieval orders yet.
Keep at it, and we'll have those tickets in no time.
Good news, Captain--pirates just logged a retrieval request in one of the cargo droids.
Sending you the crate number and location. Those tickets have got to be there--don't let the droid get them first.
Hey! I killed sixteen men to get those tickets. They're my fortune--not yours!
Rishi. As backwaters go, it's... pretty far back.
Beryl. So what have you been up to?
Got offered a privateer contract like you. Turned it down--not my thing--but I was flying war supplies for a while.
Then the Senate passed a bill saying persons with a criminal record can't fly war supplies. So it's been rough since then.
Where's your droid? Argo?
Lost him escaping Nar Shaddaa when the Hutt Cartel infighting started. Like I said, it's been rough.
What about you? Heard rumors you've been busy.
Somehow, I've ended up a troubleshooter for the Chancellor and the SIS.
After the Voidwolf, I was on Ilum, Makeb, Tython--they say the Republic would collapse without me.
Ever since the Voidwolf, I've been saving the day all over the galaxy. They say the Republic would collapse without me.
You're good, but I think someone's feeding your ego.
Sounds like what you've been through has been more than rough. You want to talk?
Thank you. No. Really, being alive makes me one of the lucky ones.
Anyway, on to business. You ever heard of Garblaque the Hutt?
That's about all the chit-chat I can take. You have a way to make money, I'm listening.
All right. You ever heard of Garblaque the Hutt?
Rings a distant bell.
Former businessman, retired to a moon of Hosko about a decade back. Pretty sedate tastes for a Hutt, likes to avoid trouble.
Now, with the Cartel-Republic alliance, he's terrified of being caught in the crossfire. So he came up with a plan.
And what plan is that?
Garblaque built a luxury dreadnaught, and he's leaving known space on a ten-year pleasure cruise. Thinks the war will be over when he gets back.
The galaxy's a big place, and I've seen how Hutts define "luxury." Might not be a bad trip.
You said it.
If he's that rich, I don't care how big his ship is--he'd have to leave a fortune behind.
That's just it--the ship is too big. He bankrupted himself, so he's auctioning off seats--thousands of them.
The war's only getting worse, and if it's over in ten years? I doubt Garblaque will like the outcome.
Maybe, but if that's the case, I'd still rather be on a luxury cruiser.
Here's the thing, though. Even Garblaque can't pay for his ship and supplies in cash. He's auctioning off seats--thousands of them.
So anyone with the money can escape the war with him.
The ticket prices are crazy--half the galaxy wants out, but only kingpins and big shots can afford it.
Think, Captain: How much would you pay to hang up those blasters and join a ten-year pleasure cruise?
To be clear, when you say "pleasure cruise"--just how nice is this dreadnaught?
Think marble floors, fur carpets, and a massage droid in every cabin.
That does sound nice.
I heard something about a "wine spa," too, but that can't be what it sounds like.
Are you looking to get out? No more jobs, no more shootouts--just a nice retirement plan?
Is that wrong? Hutts can be good conversationalists, and I'm just--I'm tired of the fighting. You must be, too.
Leaving everything to jump on a ship full of Hutts and gutless corporate honchos? Not my style.
Maybe, but think! And what about your crew? Would they agree?
What's your pitch, Beryl?
I've got a lead on two dozen tickets stolen by pirates and stowed on Rishi. I can sell them for ten times what they're worth.
We steal the tickets, we split the profits. We can even keep a few ourselves.
Haven't run a heist like this since that Imperial treasury ship. So where are the tickets now?
One last big score and we run off together in style. I can think of worse endings.
Not an ending--a new beginning.
You're a better crook than I gave you credit for. How come we haven't done this since Taris?
You, Risha, law enforcement... the usual.
So where do we find the tickets?
I like it. But out of curiosity, what keeps me from grabbing the tickets and running off?
Either honor or greed: I already have a list of bidders from the ticket auction. Trust me, you'll come out ahead.
Had to ask. So where are the tickets now?
That's the tricky part. These pirates have cargo stowed all over, and there's no way we can search it all.
But... I've sliced into their cargo droid registry. If you make it look like there's a raid on their property, blow things up....
...then they'll send a droid to make sure the tickets are safe.
Exactly. I'll tell you where the droid is heading, and you just grab the tickets first.
Blow things up, watch the droids, steal the tickets. Not a problem.
You forgot the last part: Get rich.
I'll be on the comm. Watch yourself, Captain.
Captain. Did you get them?
Got them. Two dozen tickets to Garblaque's luxury dreadnaught.
Heh. That's our way out--no more running from Imp warships or Republic customs.
Hey--wait... damn it!
Don't tell me those things are fake.
Oh, they're real. They're just designated for deck seven--"nonhumanoids and ammonia-breathers only."
We can sell them, no problem, but we're not going anywhere.
Sure, things didn't go according to plan--I got ambushed, for one thing--but we're still talking about one hell of a score.
I know you wanted to get out, find somewhere safe. You probably deserve that pleasure cruise. But you'll be okay.
You're one to talk. You could've gotten out ages ago if you wanted--you've lost more credits than I'll ever earn.
I was planning on selling my ticket anyway. No great loss.
Well, of course you're not bothered. You've earned and spent how many fortunes, now? If you wanted to retire, you would've done it already.
I'm sorry, I just--tell me something. Why are you still here? Why keep fighting?
You know why. For all its faults, the Republic is the best hope we've got.
I'm doing something good. And I won't abandon the people who rely on me.
Blast. I can actually understand that.
Sorry to disappoint.
The truth? I like the fight. I like doing and seeing things no one's seen or done before. I like not knowing if I'll make it through the day.
It's not for everyone, but I wouldn't give it up.
So basically, you're a crazy person.
I've been called worse.
Thanks. For being honest.
You may think you understand me, Beryl. But you never will. My reasons are my own.
I don't think it's that complicated. I think you just like to hurt people, and the rest is an excuse.
Guess so. The weird thing is--I think you're a decent person. But even decent people call it quits sometime.
Anyway, we can always rely on money. Something to remember next scheme.
It's not a way out, but if you want more than money, I know plenty of people who could use a smart captain and a fast ship.
Doesn't have to be privateer work. The Supreme Chancellor owes me a few favors.
Are you trying to make a hero out of me?
Just trying to get you out of my hair.
I'm not desperate for work. But for the right kind of job... yeah. All right. You've got a deal.
So--back to business.
The way you're acting, there won't be a next scheme. Quit looking for outs--learn to fight.
Charming advice, Captain.
Now about those tickets...
I'll keep my end of the bargain and you'll get your cut. Plenty of rich Hutts and Arcona out there.
Too bad the only people who can afford tickets don't really need them. The ones who've already got gangs and armies for protection.
There are nonhumanoids and ammonia-breathers out there who could use an escape. Folks hit hard by the conflict.
Yes, there are.
Ortolans watching their home on Hoth turn into a battleground. Refugees on Nar Shaddaa...
I think I can find a few dozen worthy candidates. But we're not getting rich today.
Never figured we were.
Me, neither. I'm glad.
It's not fair, but no one's hurt and we come out richer.
We do, don't we?
I should get going. If I'm really going to start working for the Republic, I've got a few messes to clean up first.
I should run. Lots of angry pirates, that sort of thing. You know the drill.
You sure you can't stick around? One drink. Maybe three.
Next time, but you're buying.
You make a fair point. What's a crime lord leaving known space going to do with his thugs?
I don't need money. Tell your buyers that in exchange for tickets, I want their people to serve me.
I don't know if I'm comfortable doing that....
If they've got a problem, I'll talk to them.
I bet you will. Okay.
I should get off Rishi before the pirates hunt me down--you know the drill.
I know the drill. I'll see you around, Beryl Thorne.
Take care of yourself, Captain--and get back to saving the galaxy. For all of us who're stuck here.
Take care, Captain. Don't get blown up.
Jamming the Eclipse frequency.
Sergeant Parisa is within five hundred meters. She'll assume a malfunction and find the relay to re-establish contact with her team.
She was the youngest--technical genius, lost her parents when the war turned hot. Callsign Blink.
Now all that's left is her body, and a computer brain going through the motions.
Jamming Eclipse frequency. Who do we have incoming?
Lieutenant Mak'eef, callsign Babe. Heavy weapons specialist. He used to be a pacifist and a card shark.
He started the fighting at Fort Klemark. Thought his fellow soldiers had poisoned his rations.
Be careful--I'm picking up a signal from Sergeant Revai, callsign Tap.
Top-tier sniper. The Rakata tech allowed him to neurally link with his weapons.
To be blunt, he was always unbalanced. The alterations only pushed him over the line.
I'm picking up two Eclipse Squad signals. They must have caught on, begun to regroup.
What am I up against?
Sergeant Noray and Captain Udanara. Callsigns Rigor and Glory Hound.
They were paired up in the Sullustan resistance before they joined. They're blasted good together.
One more to go.
You're looking for Major Nol Corovani, callsign Monarch. Eclipse Squad commander.
General Garza identified. Havoc Squad identified.
I know what we did. Fort Klemark. Two hundred dead.
Do it, Havoc. You freed my team from the nightmare. Now free what's left of me.
I'm sorry, Nol. You deserved better.
I'll see you at the rendezvous, Major. Garza out.
Orders not received. Proceed with elimination.
Orders not received. Proceed with elimination.
Target armed. Possible threat to the Republic. Recommending full-power shot to left ocular cavity.
Revanite spotted! Surrender! Die! Surrender!
Target identified as Havoc Squad traitor! For the Republic!
It's not SpecForce HQ, but it'll have to do.
Major. Perimeter report.
We're clear, sir. No enemy contact or surveillance.
Good. What's the status of Havoc Squad?
All troops equipped and combat ready.
I'm counting on that.
But you haven't disappointed me yet. I apologize for interrupting your operation--I don't doubt your objectives.
Right now I just want an explanation. There's a lot happening, and I wasn't expecting you on Rishi.
You say "jump" and we say "how high?" No need to apologize, General.
It's good having you here, Major.
You haven't been in contact for months. You can't just pull me out of a top-priority mission without explaining.
I have my reasons, Major. Do you care to hear them, or is this officially a mutiny?
Thank you.
There's a story I need to tell you. It involves a Republic Special Forces team named "Eclipse Squad."
Go on.
It started with the Rakton campaign. Your victory on Corellia was tremendous, and it's why I've been out of contact.
After what happened, the Supreme Commander wanted you on top priority, front line missions only. You were too valuable--and too recognizable--for covert SpecForce work.
That was never the intent. You're saying Havoc was a victim of its own success?
With Havoc in the public eye and the war running hot, pushing us to the front made sense.
What does any of that have to do with the "Eclipse Squad" you mentioned?
Everything, if you'll bother to listen.
Do not misunderstand. I was proud to see you and Havoc outgrow me.
Still, SpecForce needed a covert team, and no one could match your track record. I had to build a replacement.
I tried every combination of species and technology, but couldn't hit the right formula--not until your operation on Manaan.
That operation was a secret.
I have sources, Major. I sent a salvage team after you, and we dredged up the Revanites' Rakata technology.
What kind of "sources" told you what happened? Even the SIS was out of the loop.
You are still officially part of SpecForce. I know where your ship goes--I'd be negligent if I didn't.
I tried every combination of species and technology, but couldn't hit the right formula--not until an operation on Manaan.
The ocean planet?
A scientist there developed plans for building a cybernetic army using Rakata technology. Our team destroyed the lab facility and recovered the scientist's work.
You rebuilt that tech and applied it to a SpecForce team. That's what Eclipse Squad is.
Very good. We took six volunteers and made them better soldiers. They were extraordinary, at first.
Until it went wrong.
Sounds like it was quite a mission. Too bad I wasn't invited.
Like I said, you have different priorities now.
You've always been too eager to use experimental weapons, but Rakata cybernetics? What did you think would happen?
I thought we'd find a way to help win this war.
My science team reconstructed whatever Rakata tech they could. What they couldn't, they patched with replacements from the inventor Krel's blueprints.
We cybernetically augmented six volunteers. They were extraordinary--Eclipse Squad was an unequivocal triumph.
Until it wasn't.
There were... psychological effects. The team became paranoid. We thought it could be controlled.
Then a fight broke out at Fort Klemark. The fort was destroyed and two hundred Republic soldiers killed. Eclipse went dark, and I've been tracking them ever since.
Two hundred people. They must have thought Eclipse were heroes before they pulled the trigger.
So they're a rogue SpecForce team. Why are they doing this? Why come to Rishi, of all places?
Those volunteers trusted you, and you as good as betrayed them when you pumped them full of alien tech.
Now two hundred people have died? This has to stop--you have to stop.
I made a mistake. We can discuss blame in-depth, or we can solve the problem.
Eclipse is sick, Major. They believe they're serving the Republic--I think they're here investigating the Revanites--but they see everyone as the enemy.
Havoc is still the superior unit. Together we have to find them and stop them.
I'll need all the intel you can provide and a way to locate Eclipse. They won't make it off Rishi.
If they're working as a team, investigating the Revanites, then they can still reason. We can talk to them.
They have programming now, not reason. You don't reason your way to mass murder.
Maybe. What do you propose?
Sounds like Eclipse is only a danger inside Republic lines. Out here, they might do some good.
Not an option. What happens if Eclipse decides to visit Alderaan or Coruscant?
The Eclipse Squad members haven't deactivated their comm units. We can locate them within two klicks that way.
Once you're close, jam their comms using the nearest relay station. They'll come hunting you.
You're sure that'll work?
It's how they were trained.
This isn't a mission either of us wanted, Major, but it needs to be done. I'll be on your link until it's over.
Understood, sir.
Good hunting.
Good hunting, Major.
Eclipse Squad has been neutralized. But you know that.
Yes, Major.
Thank you for cleaning up my mess. They deserved better, but so do you.
Before what happened... they must have been fine soldiers. I'm sorry.
So am I. For many reasons.
You can't walk away from this, Garza. I just killed six of the Republic's finest!
Too many good people have died--Eclipse and everyone murdered at Fort Klemark.
You're more right than you know. I could cover up Ando Prime, Tavus's defection, but not this.
You needed a covert ops team and you took a risk. If it had worked out, who knows what Eclipse could have done.
You and I both know playing it safe gets people killed too.
You and I know that, but not everyone does.
I can't cover this one up--not like Ando Prime, or Commander Tavus's defection. The Senate won't ignore the incident at Fort Klemark.
Eclipse Squad killed two hundred innocent people. The politicians will pounce. My SpecForce career is over.
It's time to stop hiding behind operational secrecy. You need to tell the truth--about SpecForce's full record.
No one's hiding. I've shielded the Senate from the decisions they can't face. You should know that.
But you keep making the same choices, and people keep paying for them. There has to be accountability.
Would you testify against me, Major?
If I had to? Yes.
I see.
All the testimony in the world won't right my mistakes. I'll be stripped of my uniform; likely put in a comfortable prison.
But I know better than to pit myself against you. When the Senate calls, I'll open the record.
Don't look at this as an end. This is a fresh start--a chance to make amends.
I've spent my life serving the Republic--a few years in a cell won't stop me.
We've had our differences, General, but Havoc and the Republic owe you a debt of gratitude. You helped make me who I am.
Frankly, General--you deserve a lot worse than what you'll get from the Senate.
You've never understood. Maybe that's for the best--maybe so long as we have strong leaders, you won't have to.
I won't get in your way, but I won't testify for you either. What happens next is up to you.
I understand, Major. Sometimes a soldier has to know when the battle is lost.
I don't expect to see the inside of a cell, but I won't be wearing the uniform anymore. Still... I'll serve the Republic so long as I'm able.
I imagine you'll find something.
Maybe Coruscant Security needs an anti-gang task force.
What if there were a way to deflect some of the blame?
Eclipse Squad was my team. There's no question what they did at Fort Klemark.
But who knows why they did it? Especially since they came to Rishi afterward--a planet full of Revanites.
You want to claim that Eclipse Squad was part of the cult?
Like you said, Havoc's got prestige these days. If I report that Eclipse turned Revanite, the Senate will believe it.
It could be enough.
I'd still be out of SpecForce--two squads of defectors is one too many--but I have some pull with the SIS director.
I'd have to adjust to a new office, say goodbye to the uniform, but I'd be back to running ops within the year.
I'll be sorry to see you go, sir. Havoc owes its success to you. The Republic owes you even more.
That's enough, Major. Thank you.
Not everyone gets an opportunity like this. Don't let Eclipse Squad happen again.
On my oath, I swear it won't.
Those spies are in for a shock. They could use a little SpecForce training.
Too bad there's only one Havoc--and one Havoc commander.
It's been a long flight to Rishi, and I do need to get back to Coruscant. It could be some time before we meet again.
I understand. I've got my own mission to handle here.
Then get the job done.
I meant what I said before--you've outgrown me, and I am proud. It's been an honor serving with you.
For the last time as your commander: Dismissed.
Get to your mission. The Republic needs you.
I assure you, this room is secure.
We'd best be off. Good luck.
How are you feeling?
I've been thawed from carbonite, pierced by twenty-five needles, and injected with something I can only describe as liquid humiliation.
I'm pleased you're doing well.
I'm alright. Did you tell me--I can see stars. Am I on a spaceship?
Yes, you are. You're safe, and you're going to be better soon.
Don't condescend to me.
My apologies. If you'll excuse me--hold transmission, silence audio.
You said we'd all meet back here.
Yes, I lied. She's on her way to a private medical facility. I couldn't be sure you'd approve.
After everything we've been through, you'd still rather manipulate me than trust my judgment.
It's nothing personal. My wife has the same complaint.
Where is she going?
We both have her best interests at heart. Or am I wrong about that?
No, I suppose not.
I'm not your agent anymore, and you're no longer a powerful man. Do you suppose I won't shoot you for lying?
I don't suppose anything of the sort. But I don't frighten, either.
Shara will be cared for, in secret, by a group of richly compensated medics and scientists.
In a very slow and regrettably painful process, the damage to her brain will be repaired--and her loyalty programming undone.
You can do that?
There are no guarantees. My people say it should be possible.
When she is free, I have advised her not to rejoin the Empire's service and to make a life away from conflict. She's never had that chance before.
After we defeated the Star Cabal, I could've escaped, too. You advised me to keep working for the good of the Empire.
She always deserved better than what we could offer.
On some level, I think she hated her programming. If I'd known she could be cured...
She couldn't, then. And I know.
Shara Jenn was built by the Empire. Service is the only thing she knows. You'd take her away?
You signed up to join Imperial Intelligence. You kept fighting after everything that happened. You made choices to continue on your terms.
She never did. I'm giving her that chance.
Talk to her if you like. Say your goodbyes.
Shara? Do you recognize me?
Are you concerned about hibernation blindness or the brain damage?
Of course I recognize you. The Minister--former minister--says you helped me.
I don't want to do this, Cipher. I don't want them to decondition me.
You don't have to be scared. You're not a prisoner. Say the word, and I'll talk to the minister.
I do have to be scared. The Empire altered my limbic system.
You and I both know why you're saying that. If you could want your freedom, the programming wouldn't be very effective.
You're not wrong. It doesn't help very much.
I'm sorry I haven't been there for you, Cipher. Everything else just... got in the way.
And I'm alright--I am. I just don't know who I'll be... without.
Tell me where you are. Look at the stars, listen to the engine--that mind of yours can piece together coordinates.
You'd come shooting and take me home to Dromund Kaas? I've got enough sense to say "no."
It's all right, I think--I just don't know who I'll be.
You're the smartest person I've ever met and you're very good at solving mysteries.
I have every confidence you'll figure it out.
Maybe. But I hate mysteries.
You'll be the same woman I've admired all this time. The same woman I'd cross the galaxy to protect.
And I thought I'd been the one protecting you.
It's enough. Stay and talk--for a little while.
You're going to be a free woman with a brilliant mind and half the secrets of the galaxy. If anyone's going to end this war, it's you.
How many sides of the game do you expect me to play? But I appreciate the confidence.
I'm glad you're here. Stay and talk--for a little while.
You'll be who you've always been. An agent of Imperial Intelligence, by whatever name.
They may get rid of the conditioning, but they can't change your memories. You'll be back.
Maybe so. Stay alive, and I'm sure you'll meet the new me.
I believe our business is done. I have a retirement to get back to--and while I don't expect we'll meet again, I believe I've said that before.
You've more than earned the rest. It's been a pleasure working together one last time.
With you as well, agent.
Retired or not, you're going to watch over that woman. You'll see to it that she recovers, and you'll make sure no enemies find her after.
She's going to live a very peaceful life.
Yes, she will. But don't underestimate her, either.
There is one other thing, by the way.
I'm sorry--did you think you were in control here? That you could walk away whenever you wanted?
Actually, I thought I could buy you off.
I may be out of the game, but you're not. I hear rumors Intelligence is on the verge of reforming at last.
How do you know that?
I still have a few sources on Dromund Kaas.
Darth Marr wants you to advise and oversee--independent but with full access.
Darth Marr considers my independence to be treason.
Yes--but you'd be a check against any Sith who'd use Intelligence for their own schemes.
Darth Marr intends to divide its command between you and a Sith Lord.
To what end?
You have the experience required, and a Sith will help channel your ambition.
Darth Marr wants you as second-in-command to a Sith Lord.
What Sith Lord?
Those pieces are still being maneuvered.
A new agency will need new personnel to replace those lost. I have files with potential recruits--untraditional but highly skilled.
What kind of untraditional recruits?
Military deserters, terrorist sympathizers and Malgus's alien insurgents. All of them believers in a better Empire.
I'm always glad to have resources, but I'm not making any decisions right now.
Don't delay too long. I've heard rumors of new threats.
If we're going to survive, we need everyone who believes in any Empire working together. I'll make sure these recruits are put to good use.
If I understand the coming threats, you'll need them.
Believers in a different Empire, perhaps--but no part of my Empire.
Still, any new Intelligence will need expendable manpower. Their sacrifices will buy us time to rebuild.
They may be more difficult to cull than you expect. And you will need them.
But as I said--I'm out of the game, and the files are yours.
Watch for enemies within and without. Everything is on you now, and you know the stakes for civilization.
Our work here is finished. Best you get moving.
You're now two meters inside an Umbaran jamming field. If I've pressed the right buttons, we should have adequate privacy.
I received your message for "the Red Blade."
Yes. Perhaps a bit obvious, but I thought your pirate cover appropriate, given the circumstances.
So how is independence suiting you, agent? No one to answer to or interfering with your decisions?
I'm working with Sith more than I expected. But the cause is right, and it's on my terms.
I'm glad to hear it.
So how are you enjoying authority, agent? You haven't upset the Dark Council, I hope.
My work is in the field, not behind a desk. But it's good to return from an operation and have no one dare to question me.
You never did like being assessed.
I know we didn't part on the best of terms, but believe me when I say: I'm glad you're alright.
Then perhaps we can table our differences for now.
How are you even here? The Dark Council wanted you killed for disobedience.
So how are the Sith treating you, agent? Still a Cipher without an organization?
All the responsibility and none of the resources. But I'm making do, and the Sith know they need me.
Let's be grateful for small favors.
I didn't expect we'd ever meet again. I'm glad you called.
I appreciate the sentiment. But I'm sure you understand if I'm not here to socialize.
How are you even alive?
The last time I saw you, you expected to be hanged. You're awfully self-satisfied for a corpse.
As it turns out, there was concern that I had arranged for certain documents to be released in the event of my death.
Instead of execution, I was granted early retirement.
Sounds very straightforward.
Very. I assure you, however, I am no longer involved. I've come only to ask a personal favor.
Everything I have is at your disposal, no questions asked. Name the job.
The Empire is surrounded by enemies. The Republic, now the Revanites... we need people like you.
Not anymore. I've accepted my fate, save for some unfinished business.
Given what you did when I took your orders, what makes you think I'd volunteer for anything you propose?
To start with, we have a shared interest:
Shara Jenn. The former Keeper and Watcher Two.
Go on.
After the Star Cabal's dissolution, Shara was unwell. The damage to her brain from the cabal's trap had been considerable.
I remember her medical droid. She had trouble speaking.
Add to that her conditioning. She was programmed for loyalty, and we had her working a rogue operation.
That aggravated her existing cognitive and psychogenic trauma. It's fortunate she didn't become a vegetable.
During Lord Malgus's uprising and the chaos that followed, she was unable to protect herself.
What happened?
She was captured by the Republic. I intend to free her.
I'm guessing we're not on Rishi to attack Belsavis prison. How do we get to her?
Shara saved my life more than once. She was important to me for a long time. I owe her this.
As do I.
What does Shara mean to you, that you'd come out of retirement to save her?
She was my responsibility. That's enough.
I've made arrangements already. She was carbonite-frozen and placed aboard a prison transport, which was then raided by pirates.
And now the raiders have brought their cargo to Rishi?
Precisely. The final step is to retrieve the body and erase all evidence. No one can know what happened.
I intend to negotiate Shara's purchase from the raiders. While I do, I need you to provide leverage and cover our trail.
It won't be a problem. What kind of leverage am I providing?
Why not a clean sweep? Eliminate the raiders and take Shara. No negotiations, no witnesses.
People would start asking "why?" The SIS would piece it together. This mission needs to be forgotten, not buried.
Very well. What sort of leverage am I providing?
I'm capable of that. I'll even get you out alive. But then you owe me--understand?
I have information you should appreciate. It's yours after the mission; I expect you'll find it makes us even.
We'll see. What sort of leverage am I providing?
To begin with, I suggest you slice the raiders' databanks and transmit their files to me. That should facilitate negotiations.
I'm sure they've made indiscretions we can use. And after that?
You'll have the frequency to listen in. You know how this works; you'll find what I need.
We can rendezvous here once I've acquired the carbonite.
All right. Let's bring Shara home.
I'm going into the meeting now--keep moving, don't get caught, and delete all records of the raid on the prison transport.
Any files that might provide leverage, send to me.
Ah, you must be Trademaster Kavork of the Red Meteor Consortium.
Yes. And you are little human who wishes to trade.
I understand you acquired items from a prison transport recently. I'd like to buy the lot.
Why you want frozen prisoners?
Republic carbonite freezing units are superior to my client's. Keep the prisoners--I only need the boxes.
Do we look like jailers?
Then we'll dump the bodies ourselves. Just don't expect us to pay extra.
Maybe we sell it all back to the Republic.
Oh, I'm sure I can find a reason for you not to do that.
I'm done deleting evidence. Sending files shortly.
Sending now.
Why should we not sell to the Republic?
For one thing, I have files right... here showing that you destroyed a Republic transport last year.
Video evidence from your own ship.
How you get this?
It fell into my hands. I'm sure there's more where that came from.
Uploading files now.
I see you've also had financial difficulties.
You lie.
I don't believe so. You've racked up quite a debt to some Trandoshan pirates. Does your crew know you've been gambling?
Maybe I make sure you don't tell.
Or maybe I do you a favor. By the time we're finished here, your creditors will be gone.
Not possible. Maybe I prefer you gone.
Go ahead. Call the man you owe a debt to. See if he answers.
Boruush? Boruush!
He's gone.
Now imagine: if my people can do that to your enemies over the course of this conversation, what do you suppose they can do to you?
All right. We sell carbonite prisoners.
It's been a pleasure doing business.
What? No. Not now.
Thanks for doing this. Crysta was crazy, but I kind of liked her. If something's happened....
Thera Markon?
Stars, you're like a walking--does anything you're wearing not kill people?
You said Crysta was dead.
My mom. Yeah. She talked about both of you--she hunted for years, wanted me to take up the business, but coaching you was her biggest win.
She got a rep for it. You made her respected again. She liked that.
We weren't friends, but Crysta gave me a fair shot. Tell me what happened to her.
Crysta didn't talk much about her life. She wanted you to be a bounty hunter?
When I was a kid, she'd leave me at home while she was out chasing marks. She'd come back smiling and bruised.
I don't like bruising. She was disappointed, but we stayed in touch.
So what happened?
How long are you going to talk without paying me?
You're impatient--I get that.
I run a small shipping concern. Direct-to-customer regulated goods.
Right. Crysta got killed protecting my business from the Kanawyn Syndicate. Thugs dealing in weapons and spice.
Kanawyns have been after me for months--they want my routes, my customers. Crysta's rep--your rep--made them keep their distance.
I take it they don't keep their distance anymore.
What sort of chatter is there about this Syndicate?
I know it's pretty small--just a few dozen men, but with serious credentials. They skinned an Exchange boss who wouldn't join.
So you want them dead for Crysta? Or is this just business?
It's not just business. She was my mother.
A few weeks back, they started harassing me again. Crysta showed up. I might have mentioned your name, too.
The Kanawyns said they wouldn't fall for it this time. They said mom was washed up. They said you're Imperial now--you don't do underworld jobs.
They didn't say that. That's not okay!
Everyone says it. That you escaped the life to become, I don't know--Dark Council enforcers.
They killed mom, but I still have money. I'm putting a bounty on the Kanawyns. I want their bosses in a bloody heap.
I've done gang sweeps before. What approach did you have in mind?
I owe Crysta Markon, and I pay my debts. Forget the credits.
Okay. Thank you.
If you're telling the truth, then I have a message to send. I'll take the job.
I wouldn't lie. You terrify me.
Finding the Kanawyns won't be hard. Start at the bottom, work your way to the leaders: Avax, Chrone, and Dastid.
Avax used to be an assassin for the Chevin Conglomerate. Brutal, kind of a sadist. Chrone's her brother, former slaver, loves his guns.
And Dastid?
Worked for the Cartel until Makeb happened. Hit a colony ship once, spaced five hundred people on board. Watch out for him.
I'll hit those three after the rank and file. Where do I look?
I've got a list of their hangouts. I'll stay in touch over comm, if you want.
I want you to know--I appreciate this. Crysta would, too.
They deserve worse, you know. Killing them is being nice.
You did it. You're sure you did it? Dastid wears armor....
Trust us--armor melts.
The Kanawyn Syndicate is finished. Its leaders are dead.
Thank you. Really, thank you.
I don't--I don't like having people killed. But we had to. Not just for the business, but for my mom. She'd be glad it was you.
Crysta went down fighting for the sake of her family. That's not a lot of comfort, but it should mean something.
No. I know. I get it.
Spread the word. I don't like having my rep questioned, and the Syndicate won't be talking.
Rishi's isolated, but people will hear. Don't worry.
You wanted them killed and I killed them. No one's asking for justification.
Fair enough.
You said you wouldn't charge, but Crysta would never accept charity. I've transferred a little to your accounts.
I've got your money, as promised. Everything I have without selling what's left of the business.
Can I ask you something, though? I know you're not, like, a citizen, but--you must have opinions about working in the Empire.
You don't last as a bounty hunter by judging your clients. I stick by that. Mostly.
It's complicated, but... if we weren't doing the work, someone else would. And at least we're professionals.
Of course. I'm not questioning your decisions.
"The Empire" is a name on a map. I deal with people, and Imperials are as tough and smart as anyone. Maybe a little proud, is all.
And a little crazy. Still better than Hutts.
You want the truth? Those people don't have a clue what they're doing. But... they keep my work interesting.
Guess that's not easy when you're running out of things to kill.
So--just a thought--you must be big enough to have some authority there. Priority access, clearance codes, that sort of thing.
What are you suggesting?
Now that my business is safe, I want to expand.
You could get me access to Dromund Kaas; I could sell contraband to a whole new market. We'd both profit.
No spice, no slaves. Otherwise, we have a deal.
You're asking me to work with one hand tied behind my back.
If you don't like it, you can walk away.
No, I can--I can make it work.
If we have to betray our client's trust, I suppose it could be worse.
Some people might say you were getting soft. If they knew. But they won't.
Thank you again. For Crysta, not just the business.
Come on, Mako. We've got jobs waiting.
I'm not in the business of crime. If you don't understand that, I doubt you understood Crysta.
You don't have the right to say that. When's the last time gang trouble even scared you?
You used to work for Nem'ro the Hutt. You used to get your hands dirty!
Come on. We did what we came to do.
And if that's the life we left behind... maybe we're better off. Maybe we shouldn't miss it.
Not a bad proposal. All right--let's do business.
Will she be a problem?
No problem.
Fantastic. I promise, I'm a good partner. I'll show the capital what it's been missing--the really good stuff.
We probably shouldn't be seen together, though. So: thank you again. For Crysta, not just the business.
Will you sell out anyone? Or just the Empire?
We put up with too much from the Sith and the military. So far as I'm concerned, we earned this money.
Then you can keep it.
We're not breaking any promises. Why do you care about Imperials?
I don't, it's just--we're not criminals. We're bounty hunters. We supposed to enforce the law--our law--not break it on purpose.
After all this time, you really think I care about your objections?
You wouldn't be here without Crysta, and you wouldn't be here without me. Maybe you'll never see that.
Let's go. We've got other jobs to worry about.
I'm sorry, but I have things to do.
I think they get the point. Where do I find the leaders?
They all own property nearby. I'd say go and knock--tell them Crysta says hi.
Be careful, though--these guys are violent, but they're not stupid.
The Great Hunt Champion. Crysta's old friend. Shouldn't you be bodyguarding a Moff?
You've got no business here! We don't even operate in Imp space. What's the problem?
I'm here about Crysta Markon.
I know who you are. Guess we underestimated you. You'll still die today.
Thera--the job is done. I'll be back soon.
Something is amiss. What is it?
I recall Veijel's name, but we've never met. What do you suppose he's found out here?
Darth Nox! Everlasting night-lord!
Darth Imperius! Exalted eminence of our ways.
Darth Occlus! Eternal lord of the unseen!
It is my deepest honor to welcome you to Rishi. I'd begun to doubt--ah, but I was a fool.
You sought an audience, and I have come. The Reclamation Service will observe.
On my life, I shall not disappoint.
I was sent here thirty years ago--not for Rishi, but to stand on the brink of the Rishi Maze, the dwarf galaxy!
Thousands of unexplored worlds, just beyond the known hyperlanes. My master tasked me to monitor those dark stars.
You seek knowledge in the unknown reaches of space. Fair enough. What have you found?
You were appointed long before Thanaton. Who did you serve?
I followed Darth Arctis before his ascension, yet my loyalty is to the Empire.
If I may? What has your research uncovered?
First he demands my presence, now he tells me he's been stargazing. Does he deserve to be punished?
Hear me out, Dark Lord, I beg you!
There have always been rumors about the Maze. I admit he has me curious.
I built a deep space communications array--to watch, to listen, to try to contact the Maze's inhabitants.
And I received signals! Messages! The language is ancient, contemptuous of translation... there are Sith words, Rakata, Gree!
The messages contained instructions for improving, modifying the communications array. Even I don't understand what functions the machines now possess.
These modifications, the technology--did the signals hint what they might be for?
Only in that the technology would grant a great boon. I couldn't discern more than that.
Whoever or whatever sent these signals must have contacted our galaxy before. What could the origin be?
An offshoot species is possible. Or perhaps an artificial intellect--a lost Rakata drone in deep space.
When's the last time you received a signal?
An unknown messenger from an unexplored galaxy asks you to build something, and you do it?
They promised power, Dark Lord! I took the risk upon myself.
Alien machine enhancements. Now we know where the Reclamation Service budget went.
The signals went silent some years ago, but I believe the array is now waiting for you.
Waiting for me?
The last messages said the array required one "twice transmuted and reborn to the Mother."
Transmuted... as I was on Balmorra, and by the corruption of the Sith spirits.
And then rejuvenated by the Mother Machine of Belsavis. Fascinating.
Some distant species has been waiting for you, Dark Lord--whether by prophecy or biology. You could activate the array, learn its purpose.
By fate or happenstance, we're here now. I won't turn away from a mystery.
What does your Reclamation Service experience tell you?
My lord, my experience... says that pursuing mysteries such as this often leads even the wisest Sith to insanity. History is clear.
But curiosity urges me forward. And you have defied the odds so many times before.
Await my return, Veijel. I will examine your machines.
As you will, Dark Lord.
I thought my days of wild experimentation with unknown forces were over. It seems I was mistaken.
I'll examine your machines. Await my return.
Yes, Dark Lord. Yes!
As they say in the service, "The prudent learn; the bold are enlightened."
If I have disappointed, I will gladly pay the price.
Lord Veijel.
Was all to your satisfaction, my lord? Were the machines responsive?
"The Dark Lord's lifespan increases by a solar cycle." Does that mean something to you?
Then... it was real?
What was real?
Real! Arctis believed, Thanaton believed, but I doubted. I feared to offer you false hope.
The machines are made to increase life expectancy. Cellular rejuvenation! For anyone without your... exotic past, the process would surely have failed.
But for you, Dark Lord... those machines have granted you months or years. A taste of immortality!
"A taste of immortality." I've awaited this opportunity--but I desire more than a few extra dying breaths in my twilight years.
Of course, of course. Then grant me the means to fulfill your wish.
You're saying we've just, what--stumbled on the secret to eternal life?
Not at all. We've only just begun.
If you knew this was a possibility, you should never have kept it from me.
I knew the machines were powerful, but I refused to believe--forgive me. Let me make amends.
Grant me battalions to pacify this world. Grant me scientists to replicate the machines. Grant me fleets to explore the dwarf galaxy!
Now we know: the secret to your everlasting glory is here! We need only find it!
My lord? I have... concerns about this course of action.
You are here to advise. Advise me.
I know what you're going to say. You believe it a waste--both of time and worldly materials.
You read my spirit, lord.
Consider the wisdom of questioning my path to eternity.
Already considered, my lord--but I would be remiss to stay silent.
The long search for immortality so often leads to ruin. You saw this with your first master.
Who will count Zash among the great Sith, when she squandered her power on a fruitless quest? And now, with our Empire in such need of your resources...
I will remember your counsel. But I am not Zash.
The cost is too great, Lord Veijel, the outcome too uncertain. It is the Empire's survival, not mine, that concerns me today.
I... understand, of course.
Perhaps I can prove useful elsewhere? There are other fascinating projects under your command.
Lord Madreeg's search for lost Had Abbadon? Translation of the Flensing Rites? Your predecessors began so many arcane studies...
There is a place for research and learning in the Empire. But I will no longer sanction the dark fantasies of desperate lords.
You may report as much to Moff Pyron and help purge my domains of madness.
But I--as you command.
Find a way to serve. The details no longer concern me.
But... I am yours to command.
Give it time, Lord Veijel. An opportunity will arise, and your expertise shall serve me well.
Then I will wait with all the patience you require. Praise to you, Dark Lord.
In the meantime, I have much to do. Come, Talos--our Empire needs me.
With pleasure, my lord.
How dare you? The Empire exists to serve me! The Emperor achieved immortality, and I will do the same!
Forgive me, Dark Lord.
Lord Veijel--Moff Pyron will supply you troops as soon as possible. Keep me informed of all progress.
Yes, Dark Lord. If it requires a year and a thousand men for each month of life you gain, it will be done.
Good. For now, I have an Empire to run, and crises to see to.
All glory to Darth Nox!
All glory to Darth Imperius!
All glory to Darth Occlus!
All glory to you.
I serve you, Dark Lord.
Genetic flux analyzed. "The tesseract is fear." Subject confirmed.
The Dark Lord's lifespan increases by one solar cycle.
Genetic decay analyzed. "Redeem or destroy!" Subject identified.
The Dark Lord's lifespan increases by one solar cycle.
Mother's mark analyzed. "Someone must be sacrificed." Subject identified.
The Dark Lord's lifespan increases by one solar cycle.
Life-death balance recorded. "Beware his desires!" Subject identified.
The Dark Lord's lifespan increases by one solar cycle.
The reeds represent life and the structure of life. Feel the toughness of their forms--and within, sense the flow of the Force.
Breathe with the wind as you gather them. Smell their sap. Let the simple task calm your mind.
As you gather the reeds, feel yourself open to your surroundings. If you hear voices through the Force, past or present, do not fear.
Master Yuon is taking a new apprentice?
Once you've got an armful, on to the next step: Purity of body, purity of spirit.
Bathe yourself in the waters of Rishi. Cleanse yourself of all concerns, and let nothing trouble you.
Let the waters rid you of everything but self. "There is no emotion, there is peace."
The Hand closes. The rejuvenation begins.
Targeting Republic battle cruisers.
Now, there is a place sacred to the Rishii. Build a fire from the reeds there, and we will proceed.
The reeds are the structure of life. Now they burn, and the smoke flows inside you.
Structure and form is bequeathed to the intangible air, the unseen mind. Your thoughts gain perfect shape.
You were the best I ever knew. Goodbye, Jedi.
There is no life. There is the Force.
For the Republic!
You have achieved a Susheer State. Come, and we will build your holocron.
Not now, please!
Ah! Barsen'thor! You know how long I've been meaning to find you? Kept hoping we'd do this on Tython.
But when the Force gets pushy--says "Be on Rishi in three days! You'll know why!"--well, I make an extra effort. And here you are!
You're Master O'a?
That I am, here to help build your holocron. Can't disappoint Lara Cordan when she's trying to form the New Rift Alliance!
Oh, or the first of the Esh-kha neo-Savants, a century or so from now. He'll need good advice.
Those aren't guesses. You've had such visions through the Force?
One of my talents, but it's not always a blessing.
If the future demands my holocron, then far be it from me to get in the way.
I like you, Barsen'thor. Shall we get to work, then?
If those are visions, what you've seen can change; the future is ours to reshape.
Oh, I understand how volatile the future can be.
These days I see mostly darkness, dead planets... lots of ways the future could go.
Still, if anyone survives this war, they'll need your holocron to rebuild! Ready to start?
What do we do?
There are some nuances. It's not just a recorded message--it's an interactive program, a reflection of your mind.
A holocron can speak, answer questions... it can't think, but it will have the knowledge and memories you provide.
On Tython, I worked with our ancestors' teaching holograms. On Coruscant, I recovered the Noetikons, which contained recordings of multiple Jedi.
The Noetikons! Fabulous devices. You understand, then.
Your expertise in holocrons--where does it come from?
Habit of tinkering in my youth and a very stern Master who made me fix what I broke. But it is my calling.
If the holocron only contains what I record, what if I record a lie?
It might still work, or it might destabilize the personality matrix, crash the whole system. Try not to lie.
First thing is to scan your brain, establish a baseline. For that, we need you at a very particular level of consciousness.
On Tython, you'd use a meditation chamber to achieve a "Susheer State" of serenity. But every culture has similar rituals--we'll make do with what Rishi provides.
The Rishii people must have traditions for reaching higher states of consciousness. What do we know of them?
We don't know much about the Rishii people. What's meditative for them could end up killing me.
Granted, but the odds of it going that wrong seem slim. I did some reading--found a Rishii shamanic blessing that should work.
Just once, I'd like to visit another planet without indulging in superstitious gibberish.
If you're volunteering to return to Tython, I'm more than willing.
Speak, O'a. Tell me about the Rishii techniques.
I did some reading. There's a Rishii shamanic blessing similar to one used by the Jawas of Tatooine.
I'll walk you through it--it starts with the gathering of kishu reeds. Wear gloves if you don't want scars.
Anything else?
The Susheer State attunes your mind to the Force. That could mean dreams, visions, of the past and future. Embrace them.
I'll take you through each step on the comm, but best you make this journey alone. When you're finished, we'll begin construction.
Prepare your mind. I'll make sure I'm ready here.
Barsen'thor. The equipment is ready--try to relax during the brain scan.
The crystal matrix is developing, but it has to anchor itself on your experiences and knowledge.
I'll ask you questions as the Force guides me. The holocron will record your answers.
Ask your questions, Master O'a.
The Force grants you visions, and you ask me about them?
Just about. I've been doing this a long time; don't worry.
Swear not to repeat what you hear. The galaxy may not be ready for my teachings.
It's the role of the holocron to share your words and thoughts with those you'd choose. I won't share them with anyone.
Then begin.
The Republic may not fall tomorrow--but in a thousand futures, it falls eventually, one way or another.
I see a half-trained Jedi in the forests of Sarkhai, where your apprentice bore your holocron after your death.
The half-trained Jedi wants weapons to fight those who destroyed the Republic. She wants vengeance. What answer do you give?
I've fought every day since I became a Jedi. But nothing good comes of vengeance. I can help her control her emotions.
So she learns, and she fights, and she wins victories and dies. I can't see if the Republic is restored.
I've no desire to show people how to kill. Let me teach her to heal the galaxy, not cause more bloodshed.
It's a difficult path for her, but she walks it well in the end. She teaches others. She learns her enemies aren't her enemies.
Teach her of the Rakata and the Esh-kha. Show her the galaxy's great weapons.
So she makes war, and stars die. Her name is etched in history, at least for a while.
In another time, I see a Sith find your holocron. He loathes you. Your soldier died to defeat his great-grandsire.
He seeks to learn what made you strong; walk your path on the now-ruined world of Tython. Will you guide him?
If he walks my path, sees what I've seen and learns what I've learned, then the galaxy will have nothing to fear from him.
He does see what you saw, but he resists it--he kills--before the lesson takes. In the end, though, he redeems his home.
No. He doesn't even understand what he's looking for. My teachings aren't for him.
His fury is something to behold--but he never grows strong. He dies in battle, unmourned, unremarkable.
I'll show him my path in all its peril. If he survives, he'll emerge stronger. We gain enlightenment through fire.
He does walk your path, and he does survive. He's not Sith, by the end. He spreads your ways to the galaxy.
You already have many titles: Jedi Master, Barsen'thor, Herald. You could bear others: Seneschal, Hierophant of the Jal Shey, Betrayer of Balmorra.
Which will you choose as your legacy? When your holocron is activated, how will it name itself?
I was named Barsen'thor, Warden of the Order, by the Jedi Council. I aspire to be worthy of the name. It's how I'd like to be remembered.
I'm not my titles. I'm a person, nothing more or less, and my real name will do.
I've sought knowledge and understanding in the galaxy's darkest places. I am more than a Jedi. Let them remember every facet.
Then we're done. You've got yourself a holocron; now all you need to do is spend your life filling it.
I don't know where your next fight is, my friend. I don't know if any of us will make it through the year.
But if I outlast you, I promise to protect what we built today, if I can.
You've done me a great kindness. It's good to know that whatever happens, I'll leave behind something of value.
It's my privilege to serve a Council member.
You're a Jedi Master. I could use you at my side--there's a battle coming to Rishi.
I'm clumsy with a lightsaber and frankly a bit of a coward. On Tython, at least I can do some good.
It won't matter in the end. Holocrons are memories, and memories fade. Only the living count.
Perhaps. But soon, memories may be all that remain.
May the Force be with you.
And you.
Time I saw myself out. Good luck.
Who are you? Why are you helping us?
Not a lot of trust for strangers on Rishi. Can you blame them?
Too weak to talk, but he'll remember this.
Not only that, in a few months, he'll be back on his feet. He's a gambler, a con man--but he'll do what it takes to stop the fever on Rishi.
This one won't remember you. Don't take it personal.
But he will bring joy back into his wife's life. She'll be stronger for it, and she'll build a stronger community.
You've changed a lot of lives, but we're not done yet.
The monsoon baffles protect the spaceport during the wet season--or they're supposed to when they're not broke.
Pirates just take shelter, but everyone else spends months wading through water, miserable and struggling.
What do you suppose they'd use those months for if they weren't hurting?
You've got technical training and one of the best astromechs in the galaxy. See what you can do about it.
Wet season's going to be better next year. Folks will work better, eat better. They'll have time to sit and talk and dream of a better future.
You can do that when you're not scrambling to survive.
One more job for you, give you a little exercise. Gang war years back left a lot of buildings in ruin. All that rubble's still there.
Scrap hauler droids could do the job in hours, but scrap haulers are a luxury for these people.
A Jedi with a lightsaber and the Force, though? You could clean it up easy.
Doesn't look like much, does it? But I asked you to do this for a reason.
Better town, cleaner town, gives people pride. Gives a sense of control.
But it's also practical. Neighborhoods grow like gardens. They need space, they need to intertwine. You're pulling weeds.
How far will the good you've done go? You've changed a lot of lives here and there.
Those lives will affect others. Ripples can become a tsunami.
Next year will be better. But in ten years, these people will send the pirates packing--those who don't settle down.
In a century, Rishi will thrive. The locals will live in harmony with life and nature.
It started today, with you. They won't remember. But be proud.
It's all right. Don't be afraid.
I grew up here, you know. And I mean here--this house, not just Rishi.
Of course, I was young when the Jedi found me. Don't remember much more than the walls, a blanket and a few friendly faces....
Master Orgus.
...but it seemed as good a place as any to visit one last time.
Hello, Padawan. Got time for a final lesson from an old friend?
It's good to see you, Master. Any lesson you have to share, you know I'll listen.
Whether you'll act on it is something else, hm? It's good to see you, too.
You must know that there's great danger on Rishi. Can you guide me against the Order of Revan?
Can I? Maybe, but it's not really my place--besides, you outgrew me as a planner ages ago.
Then tell me why you're here.
You may have instructed me on Tython and saved me from the Emperor, but I don't remember us as friends. Does death make you nostalgic?
More than you'd think, and we've never been as different as you liked to believe. Don't make me haunt you.
Why are you here?
Since you set out to defeat the Emperor, you've been fighting almost nonstop. You've been waist-deep in dirt and fear and blood.
Since the Emperor's fall, the war's only gotten uglier, and there are dark times coming--for the galaxy and for you.
You've sensed what's to come?
Just a little, and I'm worried you'll forget why you're fighting.
Defending the Republic, vanquishing the Sith... those are tools a Jedi uses in the service of life, of people. Not ends unto themselves.
Every day, I face pain. I inflict suffering--out of necessity, on those we call "the enemy"... it eats at you.
That's the nature of war. I went through it, too. I want to help you reconnect.
When I fight, I'm fighting to preserve life, not destroy it. I serve the Force, and the Force is peace.
I don't doubt you. But when's the last time you felt connected to that peace?
You think I kill out of passion, out of hunger. You think I've embraced the dark side.
I'm not here to scold or tell you how to fight. I'm here to help you reconnect.
We're going to take a little time, help the people of Rishi. Folks eking out a living, good and bad, living in fear of guns and pirates.
You're going to make their lives better, as only you can. You're going to feel why you're a Jedi.
I can think of no better way to spend my time here. Where do we begin?
Master Orgus, I have an urgent mission. I know what you're saying, but this isn't the time.
Then when is? You can't go on like this, and I promise--we won't let the galaxy die because you were feeding a child.
I've surpassed you, Master Orgus, and I've surpassed the need for this kind of lesson.
Maybe so. Then humor me, and I'll make you a deal.
Whatever it is you're seeking to achieve, whatever you want to become--I'll help you when you're done here.
I've still got some tricks you haven't seen.
Very well. Where do we begin?
There are a lot of people without homes on Rishi. Those people are catching Tanamen Fever; on Corellia, they'd cure it for free.
Here, no one much cares. No one but you--your Doc can treat a person in minutes, you've got a ship packed with food and medicine....
I understand.
Yes, you do. No Sith Lords, no ancient evils this time. Just doing a bit of good.
Go and do good, Padawan.
Master Orgus?
You know, when I died--strange to say that--it wasn't my victories that gave me comfort.
It was all their faces--the people I'd helped. The people I'd served. Made the pain forgettable.
Suppose you last long enough to see the war end. How will you live? How will you find comfort, when your time finally comes?
With or without the war, I'll serve the Order as long as I can.
That means following the code and fighting if I have to. The Republic will always need Jedi.
Good friend of mine always dreamed of dying in a shop hold-up on Coruscant. There's always something to fight for.
When the war ends, I hope to be rid of my lightsaber forever. I want a quiet life--maybe on a farm, or cooking street food on Coruscant.
Sometimes the Force leads us to simplicity. I hope you find what you want.
You make it sound like the end of the Empire would put an end to conflict.
There will always be pain, and there will always be struggle. I'll dance that dance forever.
Where there's struggle, there's also hope.
What we did today--I lied a bit. It wasn't just about helping Rishi or reminding you why you fight.
It was about healing an old scar you've almost forgotten. One that still aches inside you.
The Emperor.
You were under his control. His darkness soaked through to your spirit. When we freed you, you pushed the memories of his training down deep.
I can bring those memories back. You're strong enough to handle them; let the light cure them and make you whole.
I stood against the Emperor on Dromund Kaas. I don't fear him in my memories.
Nor should you. Fear only leads to hate. Today on Rishi, you felt love.
I am whole.
I'm not looking for healing. What happened... happened. I have to deal with it myself.
Then all I ask is that you remember Rishi, and the people you served here.
I'll remember.
The Emperor immersed me in the dark side. Darth Revan was the only other Jedi to come back from that.
My memories of that time are power. That power is my right and my weapon. I claim it.
You know I think you're mistaken. No point in another lecture.
I'll give you what you asked for and hope you remember the right lesson today.
I am whole.
Then it's my time to go.
Thank you, Master Orgus--for all you've done for me. May it bring you peace.
It already has.
There's still much I wish to understand--about the galaxy and the Jedi way.
I don't have all the answers; maybe that's for the best.
You were my Master, Orgus Din, but I found my teachers elsewhere. It's past time you rested.
Maybe so.
You won't see me again, Padawan, but you won't have to. You won't be alone in the dark days to come.
The Force will be with you. Always.
Farewell, Padawan.
That was....
That was easily the toughest fight I've ever been in. I can see why Gorro fell to you.
Your hesitation does me no honor. I lost! Finish it!
[Kill him]
There. It's finished.
No, it's over.
We fought. You lost. Live with it.
You've learned not to cross me. I should think that's enough.
The show is over. Go about your business.
Frankly, I got better things to waste my ammo on.
I don't think I will. Don't see the point, really.
Show's over, folks.
I've never seen anyone fight like that... Gorro never had a chance....
You've proven your skill. Don't stand there and gloat--finish it!
No. I won't kill you.
I'm sparing you. I wish I could have done the same for your brother--please remember that.
I came here for answers, not for blood. Go.
You aren't dying today, pal. Go on--get out of here.
You shouldn't believe everything you hear. In fact, if you could tell people how I'm not a cold-blooded murderer, I'd appreciate it.
[Kill him]
You! Where do you think you're going?!
Yes, pirate scum, I am talking to you--the ones who killed my brother!
Yes, pirate scum, I am talking to you--the one who killed my brother!
I'd let the meaning of that fact sink in a second before you act....
No, you think a second--about what you have done and how you are going to pay for it!
If you and that Rodian are related, I'd hate to see what you came from.
We might not have been true brothers, but we were brothers in the hunt. Brothers in glory. Brothers in making pain.
Okay, let's see what you've got, ugly.
I am banned from twenty-six systems for acts so unspeakable we do not have words for them. This will not end well for you.
You should never have remained in plain sight, because now you die!
There you are, scum!
You kill my brother, then dare to show your face in the street? Gorro deserved better!
I didn't want to hurt him.
Your brother attacked me. I had no choice but to defend myself.
I'm sorry for your loss. I never wanted to fight your brother.
Fighting your brother was never part of the plan. But he wouldn't back down.
Gorro started that fight. I never wanted to tangle with him.
He probably saw what I see now--that you are filth worthy only of death!
You're Gorro's brother? How does that work?
We were brothers in battle! In the blood of those we crushed together!
Let's get this over with.
Idiots have been getting in my way all day. One more won't make a difference.
Your brother earned the death he got. Are you following in his footsteps?
I've still got plenty of ammo. You want to make the same mistake as your brother, be my guest.
I've had enough nonsense for one day. You want to fight me, fine. Just don't talk.
For Gorro!
Hey, now that you've got access to the place, see what you can do about opening a line for me to slice in remotely.
Security measures are down. Trouble is, so's the network. Margok must've shut it down manually.
Jakarro just sent us an update. I think that's probably enough to keep the Nova Blades busy for a while.
I've heard there's a Nova Blade lieutenant in charge there--guy named Donovarr. See if you can find him. Might have useful intel, if he'll talk.
I'm confident we'll recover Theron. See you at the village.
I would have made that shot with my eyes and the droid's eyes shut! Stupid Sith!
I understand your frustration, Jakarro, but there's only so much of your bluster I'm prepared to take.
What's going on?
Theron's been captured by the Revanites.
Data from the Nova Blades hinted at the location of a Revanite safehouse in Raider's Cove. We looked into it and were ambushed.
Revan knew we were here.
It looks that way. It's possible he may have sensed our presence; I couldn't say for sure.
They wouldn't bother taking Theron prisoner unless they needed something from him.
Were I in their position, I'd do everything I could to learn how much Theron knows.
You should have waited for me to finish with the Mandalorian clan. Absolutely stupid.
I'll concede we acted in haste. In retrospect, maybe the lead was simply too tempting for us to have trusted it.
Whatever the case, I stand by my decision to not impede in Theron's abduction--and I know Theron would, too. Now he's in a position to do what he does.
Where I come from, we value our allies! We do not let them become imprisoned!
We're talking about a seasoned SIS operative. If the Revanites took him to their base, he could learn a lot.
Of course, if we're to make any use of that knowledge, we'll have to exfiltrate him all the same.
Theron should never have fallen into enemy hands. We can't let it stand.
I wouldn't dream of leaving him with the Revanites. After all, we need to know what he's learned whilst in captivity.
Where do you stand on this, Deefour?
Me? No one ever asks my opinion--not even the hairy lug here! You honor me!
Jakarro does make an excellent point--but, then, so does Miss Beniko....
Ultimately, I think we should go after Agent Shan, as it will allow us to plow through as many Revanites as possible.
Good suggestion, droid! I will keep you plugged in for that!
Hopefully you fared better with the Mandalorians.
Revan has a fleet of warships on standby.
Of course. From examining the Nova Blades' data, it looks as though they've been routing Imperial and Republic fleets here to Rishi.
So the Empire and Republic are drawn into a full-scale battle, and whoever's left standing, the Revanites pick off.
And we still don't know who we can trust. We need to interfere with the Revanites' plans, if not stop them outright.
The droid knows where they are!
Yes, it's true. I was able to pinpoint several communications originating from another island.
I'm told there's a Rishii village on the outskirts. I can't imagine they would resent our presence there.
To the island--and Revan.
The village will be our staging area. After the Revanites fall, I will confront Revan myself.
Then we will go there immediately and establish a base of operations for my campaign. In the end, Revan will answer to me.
Yes, my lord.
All right, let's not waste any more time. We'll set up shop there and I'll see if Revan prefers carbonite or cinders.
Very well, hunter.
Their village will be remote, high up. Perfect. I'll turn this conspiracy on its ear, then see to Revan himself.
Yes, Commander.
I'm not telling them I'm some pirate.
I don't imagine you'll have to. The Rishii do seem to be very hands-off, from my understanding.
Do you think it matters to me if they mind?
I was only pointing out that they're not terribly concerned with the affairs of others.
We have to assume Revan's expecting a resistance force now; you should expect to find patrols along the way.
Tear into those Revanites, but try to save some for me!
These Mandalorians ought to assist us--if they know what's good for them.
What have we learned from the Aggressor?
Very little, I'm afraid. It would appear someone took it upon themselves to corrupt much of the data as a last resort.
It's a real mess. Getting fragments, but nothing incredibly coherent.
The one thing that does keep turning up is the Mandalorian Margok brought up earlier--the one they call Torch.
What about her?
Well, it looks like Torch and Margok were thick as thieves for a while, then something happened. Had to do with the Revanites.
Don't really know the details, but it looks like Torch moved her whole clan to another island here on Rishi. I've got the coordinates.
Jakarro, ready your ship. I'll go see what this "Torch" has to say for herself.
Beniko has other plans for me and the droid.
What's the matter, Theron--is my being around so distracting you need to hurry me off to some other island?
You're not entirely wrong....
There has to be something better to go on than an island of Mandalorians with vague motives.
It's the best we have for now, so it will have to do.
If I find anything else, we'll have Jakarro look into it.
I'm sending Jakarro out on a scouting run; I've made local arrangements for your transportation should he not return in time.
Wow, you've been busier than I thought.
Get whatever information you can from the Mandalorians. With any luck, they'll lead us to the Revanites.
My dear friend the Wrath! Always a pleasure to see you intact.
Darth Vowrawn. This is unexpected.
Well, what's life without a few surprises?
There are matters I'd like to discuss in person, and I happen to be near the Rishi System.
Perhaps we can meet? Enjoy a respite from the bloodshed and destruction?
It's past time we reconnected. I expect we have much to consider together.
I will await you at these coordinates, but do make haste. My visit to Rishi must be brief.
There are schemes at hand that require my attention. If you are involved, I would know. If you are not, then your moment is poorly chosen.
I understand your position, but I can only say this:
You are neither my friend nor my ally. Baras is gone, and our pact is ended.
What use are you to me now?
You wound me, Wrath, but I've endured worse.
We have much to gain from one another--wisdom to trade that runs deeper than war. And it may be some time before the opportunity comes again.
I will await you at these coordinates as long as I can, but I dare not linger. Good day.
Dark Lord. Moff Pyron ready to report.
What do you have for me, Pyron?
Your apprentice Ashara briefed me on the Order of Revan. We are discreetly sweeping for infiltrators in your ranks.
If I may, I've also prepared a briefing on current military operations. I'll endeavor to be quick.
...as for the Celanon campaign, Darth Marr is coordinating the joint armada with minimal losses.
That does raise the issue, however: Our Silencer fleet-killers are underperforming as the Republic adapts tactically and technologically.
We may be able to refine the Silencer cannons further, but their radiation output will begin to kill our own gunners. Shall we proceed?
Make the refinements, but post a skeleton crew to any ships so equipped. We have only so many troops to spare.
The Silencers served us well, but there's no use clinging to obsolete technology at our people's expense.
If our men are to die, let them die gloriously in my name. Continue the refinements.
Yes, Dark Lord.
There is also the question of Alzar. Darth Ravage still believes the natives hold no value and expands rapidly into their territory.
Your Overseers on Korriban believe the Alzarians might be trained as Sith, but to recruit them now could make an enemy of Ravage.
Ravage is a useful ally. He may crush the Alzarians with my blessing; we'll find new acolytes elsewhere.
Let Ravage whine at the next council meeting. The Empire needs allies, not resentful colonies.
As you wish.
Find a slaving ship willing to slip behind Ravage's lines. Anyone taken from Alzar we'll gladly pay for. Ravage need know nothing.
A clever stratagem. It shall be done.
One last order of business. I understand you're on Rishi; normally I wouldn't bother you with trivialities, but....
Speak, Pyron.
You have a servant there by the name of Lord Veijel. Like many, he's been seeking an audience since your ascension.
